Racial tensions explode on U. Mass campus
by Alex Boese, courtesy of
The Amherst Student. Reprinted with permission.
While Amherst College faces unusually low
black student enrollment, the University of
Massachusetts at Amherst has the highest
percentage of minorities ever, despite racial tensions there over the past two years.
Last October, UMass suffered the first of two
racial conflicts between its students when
fighting broke out following the World Series.
As a result of the brawl, ten people were
hospitalized, including one black student who
had been beaten unconscious.
In the days immediately following the incident, the University seemed uncertain whether
or not to call the incident a racial event. Peter
O'Neil, a UMass spokesman, said at the time,
"We don't think it was a racial incident....We
think it was just a matter of Red Sox fans and
Mets fans, some of whom were black and some
of whom were white.
Within weeks the University administration
had changed its position on this question. "The
incident has in it a major element of race,"
explained Rick Townes, Special Assistant to the
Vice Chancellor of Student Affairs at UMass.

He said that he doubted whether the fighting
was
initially
racially
motivated, but once the action began "it clearly had
a racial dimension to it."
Five of the students involved in the incident
were disciplined by the University. Three of
these five were suspended for one year. The
other two were placed on deferred suspension,
allowing them to attend the University, although
denying them the privileges of being on an
athletic team or running for student office. They
are also under threat of expulsion should they
commit another offense.
The Dean of Students Office received
criticism for its actions during this situation.
Frederick A. Hurst, a commissioner for the
Commission
Massachusetts
Against
Discrimination(MCAD), after investigating the
incident, issued a report in which he said,
"They missed the opportunity to stand up and
publicly declare the events of the evening to the
media and the entire UMass community and to
tell all that quick action would be taken."
On May 15 fighting again broke out at
UMass. It occurred at 1:30 a.m. at a party outside the Theta Chi house on 496 North Pleasant Street. The incident involved a conflict between three black student and members of the

Theta Chi fraternity. After a brief conversation
the black students left the party, but as they

Focusing on Freedom
The members of the Coalition for a Free
South Africa have yet again spoken out on an
issue of seemingly little concern for them. Last
week, the Coalition chose to attend the meeting
of the Urban Affairs Committee of the
Baltimore City Council at which it was proposed that Gilman Hall be declared an architectural and historical landmark. A Coalition
representative argued against the University's
request that Gilman not be given landmark
status; the representative said that the University is "grossly mismanaged" and that the administration "isn't to be trusted."
Although the Coalition has every right to attend meetings such as this, their place there is
questionable. Their arguments, weak at best,
suggest no real concern or commitment for the
fate of Gilman. The Coalition's attendance at
last week's City Council Committee meeting
seems to have been nothing more than an attempt to stir up controversy and gain some attention for itself.
Now the Coalition has taken on the cause of
Terry Corbett, the APL photographer who was
fired for refusing to photograph protestors at
the Lab. Although this issue has little to do with
the interests and concerns of students at
Homewood, the Coalition has managed to
smear it all over campus.
It is entirely possible, however, that the
Coalition has done the entire Hopkins community a favor, for this is an issue which treads
the fine borders of freedom of expression.
Although the Coalition argues that it is Corbett's freedom of speech which is being repressed, the situation forces us to look more closely at the role and rights of the protestors
themselves.
Terry Corbett certainly meant well when he
refused to photograph protestors if he honestly believed those photos to be potentially incriminating. However, Corbett knew of the
APL's security efforts. Yet he continued to
work there, simply refusing the direct responsibility of photographing.
It is not clearly understood why Corbett

would want to continue to work for an organization whose actions so clearly contradicted his
own ethical beliefs. But since Corbett was consistently unable to fulfill his duties for ethical
reasons, it is understandable why the APL had
no choice but to relieve him of his job.
A more complex issue, though, is whether
Corbett's objections were justified. Those who
choose to demonstrate publicly must give up
a certain amount of privacy when they do so.
The APL demonstrators are no exception. Their
protests can be seen and heard by anyone
around; hence, it is entirely reasonable that they
be photographed.
Furthermore, as APL spokesman Edward
Cochran said, there was nothing at all covert
about the photographing. It is,a common procedure for the APL, and is used mainly for their
own security purposes. Although there are those
who disagree with the work of the APL, the
Lab has every right to maintain as tight a security system as possible. If APL administrators
believe that protestors are potentially disruptive, then every effort should be made to protect their grounds and building. If the protestors
do not like this, then they should not protest
in such a manner.
Corbett believes that the photographs were
being sent to other law enforcement officials.
He has not shown any proof of this; however,
such methods have been used—even at Homewood. Last year, certain Coalition members
had had newspaper clippings about their
political activity added to their financial aid
files. Such articles and photos have no place
in such files, and Coalition members had reason
to be concerned.
But the taking of photographs for security
reasons is certainly not a repression of freedom
of expression. Neither is Corbett's being fired,
as the Coalition contends. The right to protest
is not being forfeited; it is a certain degree of
privacy that is lost. And that is simply a
sacrifice which those who feel strongly about
certain issues must take.

Breaking for the Fall
In Fall Break's short existence, the
Homewood community has tried to make the
most of the free Monday in October. The day
off is a welcome opportunity for much needed
relaxation. It lends itself to social programming of some sort, although the degree to which
this should occur has remained in question.
Homewood celebrated its first Fall Break only two years ago. A weekend-long schedule of
activities was devised in a laudable, albeit financially risky, attempt to lay the ground work for
a Fall term Spring Fair. It was regarded, at least
by those responsible for its organization, as a
major attempt to approve the atmosphere at
Homewood—particularly addressing a generally dreary first semester.
"Wild West Weekend", as the Break was
dubbed, was nonetheless a failure. Attendance
was abysmal. Students had been given the opportunity to go home and had apparently done
just that.
Last year, acting upon either reflection or
reaction to the previous Fall Break, no activities
were scheduled for the weekend. Those
students who remained and hoped to relax faced
a vapid weekend at Homewood. This year
the Fall Festival seems to have found the happy medium between the philosophical extremes
of the previous years. With its live music, food,
refreshments (including beer for those eligible)
and free admission, this Sunday promises to be
enjoyable.
For the future, Fall Festival can and should
be judged on how well it entertains the students
who remain on campus, regardless of what
percentage of the student body goes away for

the weekend.
However, despite social programming at
Homewood, many students will not receive the
mental relaxation for which the day off was intended. Upcoming tests on and/or papers due
Tuesday following Break will be necessarily
weighing heavily on their minds and their
schedules. These troubles can effectively kill
whatever opportunity to relax the extra day
offers.
Tests should be scheduled and papers assigned with greater sensitivity to vacations. This
would enable students to better relax, an activity so crucial to health and well-being.
This sensitivity regarding vacations would
also be well suited to carry over to such events
as religious holidays; the individual deserves
time unimpinged by the pressures of their
studies to at least partake in the holiest days of
their religion.
Presently, there are professors on an individual basis who are mindful of a calendar
beyond Homewood's. Often, however, this is
due to a convergence of their priorities with
students' rather than a concern for these
students.
Obviously it would be impossible to pay heed
to all legitimate personal concerns. Even to address the most popular would be,difficult, given
the full academic calendar. It is, nevertheless,
the responsibility of all faculty to account for
the mental well-being of the student. The
relatively small sacrifice involved with
rescheduling exams would produce tremendous
gains.

Fudging lab data—at one time
or another most Hopkins
undergrads either do it (but won't
admit it), or know someone who
does it. In most undergraduate

develop rules that deal with such
fraud. Dr. Cohon heads a
university-wide committee, and
says that the committee will soon
release the university guidelines.

weave, when we practice to
deceive," Dr. Alex Nickon, Pro-

Sir Walter Scott. Dr. Nickon

short vacation for minor surgery

summary of the previous six
months' work would be forthcoming. The short vacation

"smoothing of irregularities to

"cooking" is "retaining only

Racial tensions explode on U. Mass campus
by Alex Boese, courtesy of
The Amherst Student. Reprinted with permission.
While Amherst College faces unusually low
black student enrollment, the University of
Massachusetts at Amherst has the highest
percentage of minorities ever, despite racial tensions there over the past two years.
Last October, UMass suffered the first of two
racial conflicts between its students when
fighting broke out following the World Series.
As a result of the brawl, ten people were
hospitalized, including one black student who
had been beaten unconscious.
In the days immediately following the incident, the University seemed uncertain whether
or not to call the incident a racial event. Peter
O'Neil, a UMass spokesman, said at the time,
"We don't think it was a racial incident....We
think it was just a matter of Red Sox fans and
Mets fans, some of whom were black and some
of whom were white.
Within weeks the University administration
had changed its position on this question. "The
incident has in it a major element of race,"
explained Rick Townes, Special Assistant to the
Vice Chancellor of Student Affairs at UMass.

He said that he doubted whether the fighting
was
initially
racially
motivated, but once the action began "it clearly had
a racial dimension to it."
Five of the students involved in the incident
were disciplined by the University. Three of
these five were suspended for one year. The
other two were placed on deferred suspension,
allowing them to attend the University, although
denying them the privileges of being on an
athletic team or running for student office. They
are also under threat of expulsion should they
commit another offense.
The Dean of Students Office received
criticism for its actions during this situation.
Frederick A. Hurst, a commissioner for the
Commission
Massachusetts
Against
Discrimination(MCAD), after investigating the
incident, issued a report in which he said,
"They missed the opportunity to stand up and
publicly declare the events of the evening to the
media and the entire UMass community and to
tell all that quick action would be taken."
On May 15 fighting again broke out at
UMass. It occurred at 1:30 a.m. at a party outside the Theta Chi house on 496 North Pleasant Street. The incident involved a conflict between three black student and members of the

Theta Chi fraternity. After a brief conversation
the black students left the party, but as they
were leaving, a fraternity member threw a brick
at the departing car. No one was injured in the
accident.
Jay Spamer, president of the local chapter of
Theta Chi, said in a recent interview that the
three black individuals were seen urinating in
a brother's car. "When asked to leave, they
refused, "he said. "And that is when the incident occurred."
Spamer claimed that it was not a racial incident. "With the police...all racial charges have
been dropped. The press has gotten hold of it
and made it a racial conflict, but it wasn't,"
he said.
"We have a large number of minorities,"
he added, "so why would we be hostile to
them?"
The black students involved in the incident
deny the claims made against them. In their support, the police, when investigating the event
the next morning, found no trace of urine on
the car in question.
Spamer said, "Eight people saw three black
individuals with their pants down around a
car. . .They were also sexually harassing a
female."

At the suggestion of the national fraternity
the University has presented probation
guidelines to the local chapter of Theta Chi for
their approval. However, these guidelines are
only in response to alcohol violations.
"We are allowing the national fraternity to
step in,"said Townes. "No University action
is being taken for racial violations."
Townes explained that because of the stark
disagreement between the parties involved, no
determination is being made as to whether or
not it was a racial violation. He said that the
University is supporting what the national
fraternity has suggested.
The student responsible for throwing the
brick is being treated as an individual, not as
a part of the fraternity, Townes explained. He
will be allowed to attend the University this fall
if he wishes.
In response to the administration's actions,
Spamer said, "The University is trying to make
an example of us. We are a victim of the system
right now." However, he said that he felt that
the University was "being fair to an extent."
He clarified that the fraternity is being
reprimanded only with respect to alcohol violations. "We charged at the door, which is illegal,
" he noted.

Focusing on Freedom
The members of the Coalition for a Free
South Africa have yet again spoken out on an
issue of seemingly little concern for them. Last
week, the Coalition chose to attend the meeting
of the Urban Affairs Committee of the
Baltimore City Council at which it was proposed that Gilman Hall be declared an architectural and historical landmark. A Coalition
representative argued against the University's
request that Gilman not be given landmark
status; the representative said that the University is "grossly mismanaged" and that the administration "isn't to be trusted."
Although the Coalition has every right to attend meetings such as this, their place there is
questionable. Their arguments, weak at best,
suggest no real concern or commitment for the
fate of Gilman. The Coalition's attendance at
last week's City Council Committee meeting
seems to have been nothing more than an attempt to stir up controversy and gain some attention for itself.
Now the Coalition has taken on the cause of
Terry Corbett, the APL photographer who was
fired for refusing to photograph protestors at
the Lab. Although this issue has little to do with
the interests and concerns of students at
Homewood, the Coalition has managed to
smear it all over campus.
It is entirely possible, however, that the
Coalition has done the entire Hopkins community a favor, for this is an issue which treads
the fine borders of freedom of expression.
Although the Coalition argues that it is Corbett's freedom of speech which is being repressed, the situation forces us to look more closely at the role and rights of the protestors
themselves.
Terry Corbett certainly meant well when he
refused to photograph protestors if he honestly believed those photos to be potentially incriminating. However, Corbett knew of the
APL's security efforts. Yet he continued to
work there, simply refusing the direct responsibility of photographing.
It is not clearly understood why Corbett

would want to continue to work for an organization whose actions so clearly contradicted his
own ethical beliefs. But since Corbett was consistently unable to fulfill his duties for ethical
reasons, it is understandable why the APL had
no choice but to relieve him of his job.
A more complex issue, though, is whether
Corbett's objections were justified. Those who
choose to demonstrate publicly must give up
a certain amount of privacy when they do so.
The APL demonstrators are no exception. Their
protests can be seen and heard by anyone
around; hence, it is entirely reasonable that they
be photographed.
Furthermore, as APL spokesman Edward
Cochran said, there was nothing at all covert
about the photographing. It is,a common procedure for the APL, and is used mainly for their
own security purposes. Although there are those
who disagree with the work of the APL, the
Lab has every right to maintain as tight a security system as possible. If APL administrators
believe that protestors are potentially disruptive, then every effort should be made to protect their grounds and building. If the protestors
do not like this, then they should not protest
in such a manner.
Corbett believes that the photographs were
being sent to other law enforcement officials.
He has not shown any proof of this; however,
such methods have been used—even at Homewood. Last year, certain Coalition members
had had newspaper clippings about their
political activity added to their financial aid
files. Such articles and photos have no place
in such files, and Coalition members had reason
to be concerned.
But the taking of photographs for security
reasons is certainly not a repression of freedom
of expression. Neither is Corbett's being fired,
as the Coalition contends. The right to protest
is not being forfeited; it is a certain degree of
privacy that is lost. And that is simply a
sacrifice which those who feel strongly about
certain issues must take.

Breaking for the Fall
In Fall Break's short existence, the
Homewood community has tried to make the
most of the free Monday in October. The day
off is a welcome opportunity for much needed
relaxation. It lends itself to social programming of some sort, although the degree to which
this should occur has remained in question.
Homewood celebrated its first Fall Break only two years ago. A weekend-long schedule of
activities was devised in a laudable, albeit financially risky, attempt to lay the ground work for
a Fall term Spring Fair. It was regarded, at least
by those responsible for its organization, as a
major attempt to approve the atmosphere at
Homewood—particularly addressing a generally dreary first semester.
"Wild West Weekend", as the Break was
dubbed, was nonetheless a failure. Attendance
was abysmal. Students had been given the opportunity to go home and had apparently done
just that.
Last year, acting upon either reflection or
reaction to the previous Fall Break, no activities
were scheduled for the weekend. Those
students who remained and hoped to relax faced
a vapid weekend at Homewood. This year
the Fall Festival seems to have found the happy medium between the philosophical extremes
of the previous years. With its live music, food,
refreshments (including beer for those eligible)
and free admission, this Sunday promises to be
enjoyable.
For the future, Fall Festival can and should
be judged on how well it entertains the students
who remain on campus, regardless of what
percentage of the student body goes away for

the weekend.
However, despite social programming at
Homewood, many students will not receive the
mental relaxation for which the day off was intended. Upcoming tests on and/or papers due
Tuesday following Break will be necessarily
weighing heavily on their minds and their
schedules. These troubles can effectively kill
whatever opportunity to relax the extra day
offers.
Tests should be scheduled and papers assigned with greater sensitivity to vacations. This
would enable students to better relax, an activity so crucial to health and well-being.
This sensitivity regarding vacations would
also be well suited to carry over to such events
as religious holidays; the individual deserves
time unimpinged by the pressures of their
studies to at least partake in the holiest days of
their religion.
Presently, there are professors on an individual basis who are mindful of a calendar
beyond Homewood's. Often, however, this is
due to a convergence of their priorities with
students' rather than a concern for these
students.
Obviously it would be impossible to pay heed
to all legitimate personal concerns. Even to address the most popular would be,difficult, given
the full academic calendar. It is, nevertheless,
the responsibility of all faculty to account for
the mental well-being of the student. The
relatively small sacrifice involved with
rescheduling exams would produce tremendous
gains.
